awd_titl_txt: CAREER: ILETES: Informal Learning Environments in Teacher Education for STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER proposal focuses on the development of teachers' identities, which are operationalized as beliefs and practices, behaviors, and pedagogical knowledge. The PI uses a qualitative approach, occurring over two phases, to investigate the impact of formal-informal collaborations on identity development over time. The study is grounded in an ecological theoretical approach that incorporates a view of informal learning settings as learner-driven and unique in providing opportunities for interaction with objects during meaning-making experiences among groups of learners. The longitudinal research design includes collection of an array of data, including observations of teaching and learning activities, interviews, survey responses, and archival documents such as student work and videos of classroom experiences. The PI uses a narrative analysis and a grounded theoretical approach to generate themes about beliefs and practices around behaviors and pedagogical knowledge informed by informal science education experiences.

Research findings and related educational activities inform the field's understanding of best practices of integrating informal science activities into science teacher education, including determining appropriate kinds of support for STEM teachers who learn to teach in informal learning environments (ILE). The PI is integrating research findings in the revision of existing courses and the development of new courses and experiences for both new and experienced teachers. The project addresses the need for empirical evidence of impacts of ILE experiences on professional development, and will build capacity of informal science institution and university professionals to provide effective teacher education experiences and new teacher support.

por.por_cntn:
The Informal Learning Environments for Teacher Education in STEM (ILETES) project aimed to learn about science teacher education, identity and enactment in relation to their ISE learning experiences.   The project began with a narrow definition of teacher identity as being tied to and evidenced in beliefs and practices, behaviors and pedagogical knowledge.  The Intellectual Merit of this project was the expansion of theoretical lenses and approaches to researching teacher identity and enactment of science learning. Through various project activities, our definition of teacher identity expanded to center their social identities vis-?-vis their students? identities as these factors were tied to initial articulations of teacher identity.  Through a diffractive analysis of the data (where each member of the research team developed analytical questions with which to interrogate the same data set (see Jackson and Mazzei, 2011), we were able to expand theoretical considerations for teacher learning that include centering teacher learner identity?considering critical Whiteness literature, anti-Blackness in teacher enactment, dialectical materialism and science teaching as political and racialized storylines for teachers and students in urban classrooms.  Because our team members all have a solid interests and foundations in critical theory, these interrogations all centered issues of power and examined issues of oppression in science teaching and learning. 

Many of the long-term project participants were minoritized teachers who largely taught science in public middle and high schools with dominantly minoritized students.  We also learned that teachers? enactments of informal science education were shaped both by the meanings that they held about informal science learning and the goals for their students in their classrooms. The latter goals transcended science content learning to include expanding opportunities for their students to engage in science learning and practice in different ways both inside and outside of the classroom; in other words, expanding opportunities for them to develop different identities in relation to science and schooling in general.  Thus, one aspect of the Broader Impacts has been to expand teaching agency for the participating teachers in urban schools that they have been able to disseminate with peers at local, national and international levels. 

The Broader Impacts also includes a developing model of teacher identity that centers teacher agency in relation to transforming science teaching and learning for minoritized students. Based on this model, we are in the process of developing a heuristic or framework for informal science educator and teacher learning that fosters a critical lens towards teacher agency and the transformation of science learning both in formal and informal contexts.
